channel.title: Critique my PC build
channel.description:
I would post this on mitb but that part of this forum is pretty much dead. After some advice what I should upgrade/change in this build, or what I can use from my current build (upgrading my computer): [b]Current build[/b] http://www.moparisthebest.com/builds/newty.html
[b]New build:[/b] Video Card: XFX Radeon HD 7870 2GB Case: Corsair Carbide Series 200R Power Supply: Corsair CX600M CPU: [s]AMD FX-4100 3.6GHz Quad-Core[/s]Intel Core i5-3570K CPU Cooler: Rosewill 92mm Sleeve Bearing Fan CPU Cooler Motherboard: ASUS M5A97 LE R2.0 Memory: Corsair XMS3 8GB DDR3-1600MHz Solid State Drive: Kingston SSDNow V300 120GB

item.title: Critique my PC build
item.dc:creator: @chillwitm888 chillwitm888
item.description:
@chillwitm888 wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:41, topic:525014”]Okay so I’ve ordered almost every part.

I have “Kingston HYPERX 8GB 2X4GB DDR3 1600 NONECC CL9 DIMM KHX1600C9AD3B12G” memory, do I really need to update?[/quote]
Y not corsair vengeance?
Ur build could run witcher 2 on like 20-30 on max settings but not with the particle filter on
If that was on ud run 5-15 fps
I’m critiquing.

Read full topic

item.title: Critique my PC build
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

The main time I blue-screened was when I plugged in an old USB mouse that has since been replaced. It has blue screened for other reasons in the past, but I’ve recovered and cleaned out everything via ccleaner recently which I’m assuming cleaned out that folder which is why it was empty.

Either way, window 7 was still a much better OS than windows 8 in many different aspects.

Windows 8 was created to be “user friendly” which is exactly the opposite of what it really is, in order to dual boot you have to go through BIOS, turn off your secure boot feature, then load it from your USB, upon doing this I encountered that it wasn’t like Win7 where you could just automatically select your partition size and all that right there, but instead you are stuck with only being able to choose a partition to install it on, which brings you to menu with 5/6 windows partitions, at which point I decided to turn around because I was unsure if I was going to even be able to have a boot menu at start up, since Ubuntu wasn’t picking Windows 8 up.

Read full topic

item.title: Critique my PC build
item.dc:creator: @Java-RSPS-Noob Java-RSPS-Noob
item.description:
@Java-RSPS-Noob wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:37, topic:525014”]Never once had a problem, use newer hardware with up to date drivers. It is just as easy to dual boot as on W7, if you happen to install the Windows bootloader over grub just reinstall grub.[/quote]^ this

I have asked him in pm to message me with an upload of his minidumps so we can see what the issue(s) are

Read full topic

item.title: Critique my PC build
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

Never once had a problem, use newer hardware with up to date drivers. It is just as easy to dual boot as on W7, if you happen to install the Windows bootloader over grub just reinstall grub.

item.title: Critique my PC build

item.description:

[quote=“Java-RSPS-Noob, post:35, topic:525014”][quote author=4x4Chevrolet link=topic=643707.msg4333504#msg4333504 date=1373998677]
Just take windows 8 off that $1,000 build… It’s the worst thing to happen to windows, I hate it.
[/quote]Spoken just like somebody who hasn’t given Windows 8 a chance. I hated it too at first but now it isn’t too bad.[/quote]
I’ve had it for 7 months. Through the blue screens and constant program crashes, can’t stand it anymore. It’s extremely hard to dual boot Linux as well if you’re looking to do so.

Read full topic

item.title: Critique my PC build
item.dc:creator: @Java-RSPS-Noob Java-RSPS-Noob
item.description:
@Java-RSPS-Noob wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:29, topic:525014”]I never said it was unreliable–and even though it has been around longer and is more established as a company doesn’t mean anything, if I come out with a product that is more reliable and better overall than yours and my company just started, your product is now obsolete, regardless of your companys age. No one cares about that.

As for the review, I just picked two similar memory versions from PCPartPicker, same voltage, same type and speed, I’d go with the Corsair because of not only the price, but of the many reviews behind it.

http://pcpartpicker.com/part/wintec-memory-3vh13339u916gk
http://pcpartpicker.com/part/corsair-memory-cmv16gx3m2a1333c9[/quote]you do realize we were looking at 1600?

and 16gb is overkill for this budget build. Unless he plans to do some major video editing he doesn’t need 16GB. $50 RAM>120$ RAM.

AND

theoretically he could just buy two sets of the wintec I linked him to cheaper than that the motherboard has a slot for four memory slots.

Read full topic

item.title: Critique my PC build
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

I never said it was unreliable–and even though it has been around longer and is more established as a company doesn’t mean anything, if I come out with a product that is more reliable and better overall than yours and my company just started, your product is now obsolete, regardless of your companys age. No one cares about that.

As for the review, I just picked two similar memory versions from PCPartPicker, same voltage, same type and speed, I’d go with the Corsair because of not only the price, but of the many reviews behind it.

http://pcpartpicker.com/part/wintec-memory-3vh13339u916gk
http://pcpartpicker.com/part/corsair-memory-cmv16gx3m2a1333c9

pro and con for switching memory.

GO.
[/quote]

Wintec I’d vote for using in a budget build as I see it as one of Newegg’s cheapo brands, Corsair would definitively be the way to go.[/quote]You guys are calling Wintec unreliable when Wintec is older/more established than Corsair.

Corsair has great memory but it isn’t worth the difference quality wise.
